text:
I like to say that
just like Los Angeles,

the entertainment industry
helps the world dream.

And I think dreams are
really at the crux of what

motivates people to
achieve, to do better,
to help society progress.
So, I grew up in Los Angeles.

I grew up in Inglewood,
California, Lennox, California
specifically.

It's an unincorporated
part of Los Angeles, right
under the flight path to LAX.

My parents came to the
US from El Salvador,

fleeing a civil war and
economic difficulties.

My mother completed
seventh grade and my dad
completed ninth grade.

For high school,
I ended up going

to Brentwood School in Los
Angeles on a scholarship.

And Eric Eisner
started an organization

that gave students
scholarships and opportunities

to go to these
independent schools

and put us on a path towards
what would eventually
be Harvard College.

And I studied government
with a language citation
in Portuguese.

I was trying to figure out
what the next thing would

be in order to find
my passion and I

don't think I'd found it
at that point just yet.

I knew I loved
helping people and I

loved making sure that the
world was a better place.

Through incredible mentors, I
joined Warner Media's Applied
Analytics Team.

I joined their Quantitative
Data Science Team

and learned how to
code in three months
in order to have this job.

I think I found
my footing there.

I learned how to
advocate for people.

I learned how to
communicate what

it is that makes a particular
product or movie or person

competitive, and I think
being able to identify

that or replicate
that is great for me

but it's also great for the
people that I end up mentoring.

Whenever things are
difficult, my wife

is an incredible
partner and someone

who not only cheers me
up, but inspires me.

And my parents inspire me
because, man, they got here

with nothing and
yet my little sister

is about to graduate from
high school, which is more
than they did in El Salvador.

I'm about to graduate from
a graduate degree program,

and not only a graduate degree
program, but one at Harvard.

I'll be joining the
Boston Consulting Group

and hopefully joining their
technology media telecoms
practice.

I'll be a consultant there
for a time and transition
to entertainment.

I'm still extremely interested
in joining a content

acquisition team and putting
my money where my mouth is

and making sure that I can
lead a team in that space

and make the change that I want,
that I've been talking about,
right?

Because I think representation,
in all its forms, right?

Whether it's race, ability,
religion, nationality,

I think representation is
something that's increasingly
valued in Hollywood.

I would love right to have
a runaway blockbuster.

I would love to
have a company that

is doing so well
that it's profiled

in some case at Harvard
Business School.

But what I would
love more is to be

able to say that along
the way I helped people,

not just that I worked with,
but people I didn't know, right?

I want to be able to
say that I help people

like my parents, who
came from nothing

and had no advocates, no
mentors, no connection

to this country, and
yet, people helped.

It's not just about
the big things.

It's about the small daily acts
of compassion and kindness.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
